Message.Title: Do tablets really mean "the death of the PC"?
Message.Msg: Or will the same things happen to the PC after what happened with the smartphone craze. PC's still grew after many said that the smartphones will create no real need for computer upgrades. So what has the growth of the tablet, or more specifically, the growth of the iPad done to PC sales. Have they cannibalized PC sales. Let's see if this is true. Apple was the first to introduce a tablet with the iPad. Then Samsung along with other and Amazon followed. Apple first sole iPad back in Q3 of 2010. So PC sales did not compete against tablets in Q2 of 2010. At that time, about 83.3 million PC units were sold in Q2. Since then, iPad sales have grown to 16.5 million units in Q2 of 2012, while total tablet sales have grown to 24 million units. Amazon's Kindle fire which seems to be helping their stock hit all time highs, was a mere 1.2 million units. And what has happened to the PC sales? Total PC sales for Q2 of 2012 was 87.4 million units. So PC sales actually grew in Q2, even with it maturity and worldwide slowdown in GDP growth. Specifically, the stall in growth of Europe. So does this mean tablets are cannibalizing PC sales? I guess not since the growth of tablets to 24 million units per quarter should have taken a big chunk of PC quarterly sales. PC sales actually grew by about 4 million units during that period. And the tablet market share for anybody but Apple is pretty sad. Take the so called popular Kindle by Amazon. Number 3 in sales yet only 1.2 million units sold. The last place PC seller Asus sold over 6 million units, or five times Kindle Fire sales. And Kindle sold 1.2 million units at a price that was way below cost. This is what they call tablets cannibalizing PC sales? Oh, by the way, all other vendors besides the top five sold a total of 36.5 million units. So more vendors seem to be successful in PC sales while only Apple seems to be successful in tablet sales.

Topic.Title: Do tablets really mean "the death of the PC"?

Message.Msg: I think you are absolutely right, and thanks for a great post. No serious writer, composer, executive, scientist, engineer, student, etc etc is going to replace a PC with a tablet. The physical keyboard/mouse is the optimal user interface and the feature ensemble on PC's, particularly next gen "ultrabooks" will outpace and outgame the tablet. If you need to be in tablet mode an ultrabook offers that option, but also allows you to go back to being a grown-up in PC mode.. If you want to switch op systems to, eg, ubuntu linux, PC's offer that option...tablets?. The massive arsenal of professional software runs on PC's and a tablet would simply not be up to the task (try running and composing a symphony in Sibelius 6 on a tablet; or do Mathematica, or adobe photoshop, on a tablet, etc). Aside from being a novelty the functional flexibility and utility of tablets is so limited that they will frustrate a wave of users who will return in the next cycle to the modern PC. I predict tablets will ultimate rejoin PC's as a "detachable screen" mode. This is the INTC vision of things and I believe it is correct. Regarding the "warning": We are seeing a confluence of effects on the PC market at this moment: (1) Windows 8 is pending, (2) China is slowing; (3) Europe is slow; (4) the AAPL novelty shop is peaking (5) An idiot is seeking the Presidency (6) a hoard of idiots who call themselves analysts are trying to wreck Intel. But remember, INTC is 30% PC's, 25% Servers, 15% Atoms in everything, 30% other. Only the PC part of this is getting rocked temporarily. Fasten your seatbelt and collect your dividend. We'll weather this and be back to the targets beyond $30 in no time. Intel is numero uno and will remain so indefinitely far into the future.

Topic.Title: Apple goes with TSMC 20nm 2014

Message.Msg: Something to think about, all those iPads sold a starting a couple of years ago will be starting to have their batteries die in a year or two. Right now if you bought the original iPad2 it probably isn't holding the charge as long as it used to . The original iPad probably can't hold half it's charge by now. So what? If you have the skills to replace the batteries yourself it's under $50, to send it out to some no name service is $100. Or you can look into a new one. If by the end of 2014 there isn't something exciting like a TSMC 20nm processor in the newest iPad I don't think you'll see many consumers buying new ones nor getting their old ones fixed. Think the PC revolution is dead? Just wait until consumer throw out iPads in bulk. Something you spent over $500 a few years ago is a lot of money to just throw away.

Topic.Title: Do tablets really mean "the death of the PC"?

Message.Msg: Two very good posts. The change in the PC format has been a continuum since the 1980s Remember the "luggable" portables from Compaq? My first clamshell notebook weighed over 10 lbs! Changing formats in the name of this game. An A5X chip in a PC back in the 80s or 90s would have seems like a miracle, today it is too slow for any real contect creation. I bought my wife a full boat iPad (1 kilobuck) I tried it just for web surfing. I was so frustrated with it that I damn near "frisbeed" it off the deck. I got head of it on surfing to the point that I didn't know what I was waiting for.....and then it locked up! I think they have a real product with and entry level x86. Maybe more than an Atom. Maybe dual Atoms make a usable machine. I just bought a Macbook Air. I'm not interested in learning window 8. It's a torture learning Apple from PC. I think windows 8 will not provide the pop in PC buys this time. The format (Air, Ultrabook) will be hot once they get on some shelves. Another reason for the Air is that for $99 they transfer my data and I get as many one on one session as I can jam into a year. Windows needs to do something like this. For all the years I used a PC I felt like I was playing a video game without knowing the rules:) Tablets are toys until they get the performance up a few notches. I'm still holding onto the hope that Wed will bring a huge Apple/Intel announcement. I still can't see where Ottelini is scheduled for any appearance at the Developers Forum...Very strange.

Message.Title: There's a Reason
Message.Msg: There's a reason why Intel announced the reduction in the revenue estimate prior to the start of IDF on Tuesday and the imminent smartphone announcements. Just like with the last revenue warning, Intel is a master of managing the impact. This timing is designed to do the same thing. We've had the bad news, now we get the good news. And so the move back up begins. Not to mention the jobs numbers will likely generate more stimulus efforts when the Fed meets this week. And Windows 8 coming up in October which is a primary factor in the Q3 weakness as people are waiting to buy. In the meantime Wall Street's biggest firms will continue to do everything they can to prevent economic recovery as they have bet big on doom and gloom and literally can't afford to be wrong. They will continue their efforts to keep Intel's P/E ratio in the grossly under-valued range. Why do Wall Street's biggest firms constantly attack one of America's best companies? Let's get some answers. Send the letters...

Topic.Title: Apple goes with TSMC 20nm 2014

Message.Msg: This is the usual fanboi distortion. Here's what was actually said: " (TSMC) is expected to get processor orders from Apple in 2014, after the company enters 20-nanometer manufacturing, predicted institutional investor UBS yesterday." The fanboi clearly has translated "is EXPECTED to get" into "has gotten" and clearly doesn't understand what the word "PREDICTED" means. But all that aside, this is great news for Intel. Apple not getting state-of-the-art technology until 2014!!! Wow, that's terrific news. Intel is going to own mobility by 2014. So if Apple doesn't upgrade until then and then only gets pathetic 20nm that gives Intel a huge competitive advantage. And that's if TSCM pulls it off by 2014, which is unlikely. Maybe 2015. Maybe later. After all, they are still struggling to master 28nm. If Apple wants to wait that long to move into 2nd rate technology, that's fine by me. Game over...

Topic.Title: NEXT BOARD MEETING

Message.Msg: IMO, "today". I have not found any public information that describes their meeting dates or information about what they discussed. The only "clue" that I could even point to would be the "dividend declaration date". That is the the DAY that Intel announces the dividend approved by the BOD and so it should be right after the BOD meets. There seems to be a historical trend for mid-September, similar to the SF IDF. I would guess that the BOD meets shortly before the San Francisco IDF to get an update on status, approve what is going to happen and what announcements to make. The historical dates taken from the NASDAQ dividend history page for Intel shows the Q3 dividend dates: 9/21/2011 9/23/2010 8/1/2009 10/27/2008 9/29/2007 9/12/2006 Historical dates of SF IDF from Wikipedia: San Francisco IDF 9/13/2011 9/13/2010 9/22/2009 8/19/2008 9/18/2007

Message.Title: Romney says he would keep parts of Obama healthcare law HAA HAA
Message.Msg: Romney says he would keep parts of Obama healthcare law WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who has called for scrapping President Barack Obama's 2010 U.S. healthcare law, said in remarks aired on Sunday that he likes key parts of "Obamacare" despite his party's loathing of it and wants to retain them. Romney, who faces Obama in the November 6 election, has vowed throughout the campaign to repeal and replace the Obama healthcare law. But asked about the Obama healthcare law on NBC's "Meet the Press" program, Romney said, "Well, I'm not getting rid of all of healthcare reform." "Of course, there are a number of things that I like in healthcare reform that I'm going to put in place," Romney added. "One is to make sure that those with pre-existing conditions can get coverage. Two is to assure that the marketplace allows for individuals to have policies that cover their family up to whatever age they might like." Funny but I was sure he said he would repeal all of it? Yeah and you rightwing teabagging nimrods voted for him because he said as much in the primaries. But now he says he will not repeal all of it. HAAAA HAAAA I think Romney has SCREWED you Rush dumbaugh loistenning teabagging losers.

Message.Title: Intel's developer forum - what to expect
Message.Msg: From EETimes: If you think the biggest event of next week is the Apple press conference, you’re clearly not a chip-head. For those of us deeply embedded and ensconced in the world of semiconductor hardware, Intel’s yearly developer forum (IDF) held in San Francisco’s Moscone center is still a yearly highlight and this year won’t disappoint. We’ve been told that this year’s x(86)travaganza will revolve mainly around three topics; perceptual computing (or natural user interface), touch and convertible, and of course all the news around Intel’s low power 4th generation core processors, which are said to be doing better than expected. All in all, not a bad line-up. Let’s take a look at each in slightly greater detail.

Topic.Title: Intel's developer forum - what to expect

Message.Msg: At the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas back in January, Intel already set the scene for its future perceptual aspirations with talk of voice recognition integration, but touch is the next big thing coming to Ultrabooks with Windows 8. Even touch, however, is just the beginning, with Intel making big bets on a not-too-distant future where embedded cameras and sensors (amongst other things) will recognize hand gestures, faces, and enable better voice processing, while allowing users to control their screens in more interactive, personalized ways. At IDF, Intel will apparently be showcasing several initiatives which will help enable hardware and software developers to drive perceptual computing aggressively into Intel platforms starting this year. If this is what peaks your interest, we’re told executive vice president and general manager of Intel’s mobility group, David (Dadi) Perlmutter, will be discussing it at greater length during his keynote on Tuesday September 11.

Topic.Title: Intel's developer forum - what to expect

Message.Msg: Touch and convertible to the PC Touch is coming to the ultrabook in a very big way, and Intel is betting that people will fall in love with it. The firm says that overwhelmingly its research has shown that when people were given an ultrabook with touch, they automatically used the feature in 80 percent of their applications, even claiming to feel a better emotional connection to their device. Microsoft Windows 8, of course, is specifically designed with touch in mind, and OEMs are refreshing their systems with touch capabilities in time for this coming holiday season. Intel will be touting 40 touch-enabled ultrabook design wins in the pipeline, which insiders say consumers should expect to see before this year’s end.

Topic.Title: Intel's developer forum - what to expect

Message.Msg: Convertibles and 4th generation cores For those who like a bit of a blend, melding ultrabook laptops with tablets, Intel believes its new convertible designs have the potential to bring the best of both worlds together in one platforms. We’re told there will be a number of new designs coming out -- some recently released last week at IFA in Berlin and many to be found onsite at IDF. The new convertibles are showing up in all shapes, sizes and SKUs, differentiating themselves with a plethora of sliders, swivels, flip screens, dual screens and more. Indeed, the focus for this holiday season appears to be strongly based around personalization, with a lot of choices depending on personal preference. Intel has a number of ultrabook systems in convertible designs on the way from OEMs including Asus, Dell, Lenovo, Panasonic, Sony and Toshiba, which will all be on display at IDF. On the tablet front, Intel has over 20 design wins from leading OEMs based on its next generation Atom SoC (Clover Trail), with a number of them in convertible designs. Sources say this is just the first step for convertibles, as Intel pushes towards its next generation Intel Core processor family, and arguably the most exciting news of the show.

Topic.Title: Intel's developer forum - what to expect

Message.Msg: 4th generation Intel Core processor family Last year Intel set out to reinvigorate the industry around ultrabooks and said it would cut the mainstream mobile processor design power in half to enable this new category of laptops. The firm intercepted a product cycle half way through in 3rd generation Intel Core to bring power down from 35 watts to 17 watts, resulting in thinner, more innovative computing devices, represented by the touch and convertible designs available already today. Intel is purportedly pleased with these initial systems, and is getting ready to ramp things up another notch. Initially the firm had said its 4th generation Intel Core processor SoC (due out in 2013) would be the first chip built from the ground up with the ultrabook in mind. Now, the firm is saying that it’s going even better than originally expected. Indeed, things are going so well on the technical side that the firm is even said to be making more changes in its flagship core roadmap, starting with the 4th gen core in 2013, to help OEMs make even thinner and lighter designs. Specifically, we’re told, Intel will be introducing a new line of low power chips targeted to operate at around 10 watts initially, while offering other 4th Gen Core processor benefits like high performance, low idle power, single-chip packaging, and new graphics and security capabilities. Intel is said to be “really excited” about the possibilities this will open up for more innovation in the PC. And let’s face it, in an increasingly mobile world, the PC sorely needs a facelift. If IDF delivers, and I believe it will, it should be a great show this year.

Message.Title: What's Fair
Message.Msg: The question of what is fair is pretty easy. What's fair is a distribution of taxation that allows the middle class to grow. We haven't had that in 30 years. So the middle class is getting rubbed out. You damage the middle class beyond a certain point and the US economy will collapse. We are nearing that point and still the rich just can't get enough tax cuts. Just because you want a tax cut doesn't mean it's fair. How do we know the tax rate is already fair to the rich? Because they keep getting richer and every day own more and more of the wealth in America. The rich are not suffering. But the middle class sure is. Go ahead. Destroy the middle class. And the rich will go down with it...

Message.Title: Jobs rut tips scales in favor of Fed stimulus
Message.Msg: From Reuters: The Federal Reserve looks set to launch a third round of bond purchases this week to try to drive borrowing costs lower and breathe more life into an economy that is not growing fast enough to lower unemployment. Despite political opposition and some internal dissent, economists said a weak report on jobs growth for August was likely enough to convince the U.S. central bank a looser monetary policy was needed. "The Federal Reserve will ease again," said Sung Won Sohn, an economics professor at California State University Channel Islands in Camarillo, California. "There are too many people without jobs and the unemployment rate is too high at this stage of an economic recovery." [IDF and more stimulus. Prolly not enough to get Wall Street largest firms to put their "Bash Intel" campaign on hold. Write the letters...]

Topic.Title: I will explain how Intel failed and how they will never recover.

Message.Msg: Vinnie youre a sad little F*** who thinks he knows a lot but you have no clue and nooo patience. do some research and stop going around spamming message boards preaching your crappy beliefs. Another thing INTEL DOES NOT ONLY MAKE COMPUTERS...THEY MAKE COMPUTER CHIPS and the HARDWARE FOR THEM AS WELL UNLIKE MANY OTHER TECH COMPANIES. This gives them some diversification which will always be needed for any company producing computers. There will always be a need for such products so im sorry to say to you that INTEL WILL BE HERE FOR AWHILE. Next, R and D is #$%$ incredibly important for companies like intel....technology doubles every 6-7 #$%$ years and they have to stay on top of their #$%$ and ahead OR AT LEAST WITH THEIR COMPETITION...even if it mean copying them a little. Furthermore Intel has only experienced weaker sale for their computer because of the increase demand for TABLETS...WHICH THEY DONT MAKE. SO once again and on behalf of everyone on this board #$%$ off and learn how to make rational comments instead of coming in and blasting a company that has been around for sometime and has managed to maintain a significant portion of its market while also keeping up with the rise of new competitors.

Topic.Title: I will explain how Intel failed and how they will never recover.

Message.Msg: and another thing...Intel has just contacted to meet with "tablet experts" which might indicate future plans to enter the tablet market.......you dingleberry
